III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 3/17/25, a youth jammed their finger while playing basketball
and they reported this to staff, but the youth was not assessed by
medical staff. On 3/19/25, the youth's finger was very swollen and
they could not move it. On 3/20/25, the youth was taken to urgent
care and was diagnosed with a broken finger.
Investigation Interviews:
Foster Care Worker was interviewed via phone on March 21,
2025- Foster Care Worker reported she had been assigned to
Youth A’s case for about three weeks. She reported on March 19,
2025, she picked up Youth A from the facility to transport him to
his new foster home. When they were in the car, Youth A showed
Foster Care Worker his finger which was swollen, and he reported
to be in pain. Foster Care Worker reported Youth A told her he
hurt his finger while playing basketball at the facility on March 17,
2025. She reported Youth A stated he told someone at the facility
about the situation, but he did not remember who he talked to or
what he said. Foster Care Worker reported she did not go back
into the facility to talk to them about what happened as they were
already in the car heading to the new placement. She reported the
facility never told her that he had gotten hurt or provided any
incident report. Foster Care Worker reported Youth A’s new
placement had taken him to Urgent Care where it was found that
his finger was broken down by the knuckle and would need further
medical treatment.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at his foster home on
March 22, 2025, by MDHHS Woker 2, this consultant was
available via phone. Youth A reported, on Monday, March 17,
2025, he was playing basketball at the facility with some other
youth. He reported when he went to jump up to get the ball, the
other youth also jumped up and he ended up hurting his finger.
Youth A reported he thought he had jammed his finger and Staff 1
tried to help him un-jam his finger. He reported the facility
provided him with ice and ibuprofen for his finger. Youth A
reported he did tell Supervisor that he had hurt his finger, and he
wanted to get medical attention, he reported she said that they
2

would keep an eye on his finger to see if the swelling would go
down. He was asked if there is a nurse at the facility and Youth A
reported there is no nurse at the facility. When asked if he had
pain when this incident happened, Youth A reported that he does
not experience pain because he has superpowers. Youth A
reported he showed his Foster Care Worker his swollen finger on
Wednesday, March 19, 2025, when he was getting moved to his
new foster home. He reported his Foster Care Worker told his
foster parents to bring him into urgent care and they found his
finger to be broken. He reported he did not want to get the facility
in trouble as the staff are good people there.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on March
25, 2025, by MDHHS Woker 1, this consultant was available
via phone. Staff 1 reported he worked on March 17, 2025, March
18, 2025, and March 19, 2025. He does remember working with
Youth A and they played a lot of sports together. Staff 1 reported
one day, he could not remember which day, he was going to play
catch with Youth A, but Youth A stated he couldn’t because he
hurt his finger. He reported he did look at Youth A’s finger and
saw that it was swollen. Staff 1 reported Youth A never told him
how he caused his finger to get hurt but Youth A did report the
feeling of it being jammed. He reported he did try to help Youth A
with his finger, but Youth A reported he was already getting ice
and ibuprofen for it. Staff 1 reported he remembered asking Youth
A if he went to the hospital to get his finger looked at and Youth A
reported he did not. He reported he did offer to get Youth A
medical help, but Youth A reported he did not want any because
he was “not a pussy”. Staff 1 reported he did not complete an
incident report or inform a supervisor about this because Youth A
made it appear that someone already knew about it as he was
getting ice and medication. He reported Youth A never came up to
him after playing basketball stating he hurt his finger. Staff 1
reported he never remembered seeing or hearing about Youth A
actively hurting his finger and only noted about seeing it after the
fact. He reported if Youth A had initially hurt his finger while
playing basketball, Staff 1 would have completed an incident
report and information to the supervisor on shift. Staff 1 reported
the supervisor would then have Youth A go out to the hospital for
a medical assessment.
Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on
March 25, 2025, by MDHHS Woker 1, this consultant was
available via phone. Supervisor reported she did work with Youth
A on March 17, 2025, March 18, 2025, and March 19, 2025. She
denied ever hearing any concerns about Youth A hurting his finger
3

or wanting medical attention. Supervisor reported she does not
even remember seeing Youth A’s finger swollen because if she
did, she would have been sent out Youth A for a medical
assessment at the local hospital. She reported if she was made
aware of Youth A hurting his finger the staff member or herself
would complete an incident report. Supervisor reported she looked
through Youth A’s file and there was no incident report of hurting
his finger. She reported she would have provided him with ice and
ibuprofen to help. Supervisor looked through Youth A’s medical
chart and there was no documentation of Youth A receiving any
ibuprofen on any of those reported days.
Therapist was interviewed face to face at the facility on March
24, 2025, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker 1. Therapist
reported he worked with Youth A at the facility. He stated the last
time he met with Youth A was March 18, 2025, and Youth A did
not report any concerns about his finger. Therapist reported he
does not remember seeing any concerns with Youth A’s finger. He
reported that if Youth A had complained of hurting his finger, staff
would have taken him to the hospital if it was swelling and
provided him with ice as well. Therapist reported he did not find
any incident reports in March 2025 about Youth A hurting his
finger while playing basketball.
Administrator was interviewed via phone on March 27, 2025.
An update was provided to Administrator about the investigation.
She reported she saw Youth A on March 18, 2025, and just before
he discharged on March 19, 2025. Administrator reported Youth A
had no complaints of any pain and never showed her his finger.
She reported supervisors are the only ones to provide medication
to the youth so Staff 1 would never have provided any medication.
Documentation Reviewed:
- Staff 1’s Human Resource File- Staff 1 has four written
warnings within his human resource file. One warning was
due to not using the appropriate restraint technique, two
warnings were because of attendance, and the fourth
warning was due to not following the mandated reporter
policy. Staff 1 is in compliance with all training
requirements, which included review of incident reporting
and medical procedure policy in April 2024.
- Supervisor’s Human Resource File- Supervisor has three
written warnings within her human resource file. Two of the
warnings are due to attendance and one is due to
4

Supervisor using inappropriate communication with a youth
when the youth was physically aggressive. Supervisor is in
compliance with all training requirements, which included
review of incident reporting and medical procedure policy in
May 2023.
- Youth A’s Medical File- There was no documentation
noting Youth A had hurt his finger. There was no
documentation noting Youth A received ibuprofen on March
17, 2025 through March 19, 2025.
- Facility’s Health related resources, procedures and
oversight policy- This policy notes all youth receive
ongoing, coordinated services based on assessed needs
and goals. All staff are oriented to the method of accessing
health and medical services for youth as appropriate. Staff
are able to use emergency medical services when needed
for the youth. Staff 1 did offer Youth A medical services
when he witnessed the swollen finger, but Youth A denied
these services.
- Facility’s Critical Incident Response and Reporting
policy- This policy notes that a critical incident should be
documented if there is a physical injury to a youth or in
need of emergency medical treatment. Staff 1 did not
complete an incident report form as Youth A reported this
happened prior, was already getting medication and when
offered medical treatment he refused.
Analysis The facility is found to be in rule compliance. Youth A reported
Supervisor was the one to deny him access to get medical
treatment for his finger. Supervisor reported she was never aware
of Youth A harming his finger and noted that he never was
provided any ibuprofen for pain. Staff 1 found out Youth A had
hurt his finger when he tried to play catch with Youth A, not when
his finger was initially hurt. Staff 1 reported Youth A stated he had
hurt his finger in another incident and was provided medication.
He reported Youth A also denied wanting any medical treatment
and did not note any concern. Due to all the information from
Youth A, Staff 1 believed the situation was already handled. Staff
1 and Supervisor were knowledgeable about the process of
getting a youth medical treatment for any injury that occurred.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
5

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
